quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: my goal here is to help you get better at the craft of building and growing products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames product management as a learnable craft focused on building and growth, setting a practitioner-oriented lens for the episode.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Ian has managed over 100 product managers in his career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes the scale of Ian’s leadership experience, implying the advice is grounded in extensive real-world management patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we focus primarily on two topics. What separates a top 1% PM from everyone else, specifically for new PMs and also for senior PMs. And we also dig deep into the working backwards process.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces the episode’s two core frameworks: differentiators of top PM performance and Amazon’s working-backwards methodology.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And we also dig deep into the working backwards process. We get into how you can implement the process on your team and how you might be doing it wrong.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology plus a warning that teams often misapply it—useful for diagnosing and improving process adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And when it comes to using data, a lot of teams think that they only have two choices. Make quick decisions based on gut feelings or make data driven decisions at a snail's pace. But that's a false choice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Challenges the common speed-vs-rigor tradeoff in product decisions, asserting teams can avoid the gut-vs-slow-data dichotomy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And when it comes to using data, a lot of teams think that they only have two choices. Make quick decisions based on gut feelings or make data driven decisions at a snail's pace. But that's a false choice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Challenges the common speed-vs-rigor tradeoff in product decision-making and reframes it as an avoidable false dichotomy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You shouldn't have to compromise on speed to get product answers that you can trust.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise principle practitioners can use to set expectations for analytics and decision workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One, with a small scoop that dissolves in water you are absorbing 75 vitamins, minerals, probiotics, and adaptogens.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, concrete data point used to justify a simple daily routine with broad nutritional coverage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Two, they treat AG1 like a software product. Apparently they're on their 52nd iteration and they're constantly evolving it based on the latest science, research studies and internal testing that they do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a transferable methodology—iterating a non-software product with software-style continuous improvement loops.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Ian’s “Top 1% PM” post
quotes.text: Definitely not.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that high-impact work (like writing) often isn’t predictable at the time you create it.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Ian’s “Top 1% PM” post
quotes.text: I used to look for questions in the Goldilocks zone. They weren't too high level of abstract like how do you be a good problem, but they weren't too super specific and this one was kind of right in the middle.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A practical content/learning framework: target problems that are neither too abstract nor too narrow to maximize usefulness and engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Ian’s “Top 1% PM” post
quotes.text: And so I'd pluck off a couple of those and I think more as a way to structure my own thoughts, that was what was interesting and fun for me to do that. Not because I thought it'd have any kind of real reach.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Actionable advice: write primarily to clarify your own thinking; external impact can be a byproduct rather than the goal.

quotes.topic_title: Power of writing and online connections
quotes.text: I think the value for me was so awesome just to make connections with people in the industry
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Highlights writing as a practical career lever for building industry relationships, not just sharing ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Power of writing and online connections
quotes.text: But obviously I'd credit this work and those relationships for me ultimately going there and so many great relationships and people I've met because of it.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A concrete example of online writing translating directly into real career opportunities via relationships.

quotes.topic_title: Power of writing and online connections
quotes.text: just summarize something that you've been thinking about that you want to just crystallize in your own head.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable starting point for writing: use it to clarify your own thinking, which often becomes valuable to others.

quotes.topic_title: Power of writing and online connections
quotes.text: you've got to be a clear thinker to be a clear communicator.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A memorable mental model linking writing quality to thinking quality—use writing as a test of clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Power of writing and online connections
quotes.text: So there's two tests in writing well or communicating well. It's both those things.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Defines a simple two-part framework for effective business writing: clear thinking + clear communication.

quotes.topic_title: Ian’s career journey across major companies
quotes.text: So after doing finance and economics in school, I made the logical choice and I got a job doing marketing in the beer industry and then the next logical choice, I moved to Tokyo and I bootstrapped my way into software development without knowing Japanese or software development.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive career-building approach—taking unconventional leaps and learning by bootstrapping into new domains.

quotes.topic_title: Ian’s career journey across major companies
quotes.text: And that was really the start of when I think about building my product toolbox and leadership toolbox.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: treat roles/companies as deliberate opportunities to build a “toolbox” of product and leadership skills.

quotes.topic_title: Ian’s career journey across major companies
quotes.text: I led Alexa International, so scaling Alexa and Echo to six more countries.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A concrete example/data point of scope that signals the kind of scaling experience that builds strong product leadership capability.

quotes.topic_title: Ian’s career journey across major companies
quotes.text: The way I think about it is that I've done a whole bunch of different lifetimes, especially around eCommerce, and so it allows me to cover the gamut.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A useful framing for practitioners: accumulate “lifetimes” (distinct chapters) within a domain to broaden coverage and pattern recognition.

quotes.topic_title: Attributes of top 1% product managers
quotes.text: What separates product managers from consultants sometimes is you forecast and then you execute and then you measure and validate and that helps you build your instincts.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A clear methodology for building product judgment: make predictions, ship, then validate to improve instincts over time.

quotes.topic_title: Attributes of top 1% product managers
quotes.text: trust is the currency of a product manager and a product leader, especially if you're going to grow in your career.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes career growth as primarily driven by trust-building, not just output.

quotes.topic_title: Attributes of top 1% product managers
quotes.text: Digging for data. It's out there and you got to develop the tools to go find it. Not to depend on your analyst or what's in the reports today.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Actionable advice for PMs to become self-sufficient in data access rather than relying on others or prebuilt dashboards.

quotes.topic_title: Attributes of top 1% product managers
quotes.text: Because if you say yes to everything, you're going to go nowhere.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A blunt, quotable reminder that effective pushback is essential to prioritization and leadership progression.

quotes.topic_title: Attributes of top 1% product managers
quotes.text: Ultimately that's what you want to wake up every day thinking about how to have an impact for your business and that will be an indicator on your likelihood of promotion. So do that instead of just focusing on how to get promoted and having that guide your day.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career heuristic: optimize for impact first, and promotion becomes a byproduct.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for new PMs
quotes.text: Probably communicate, prioritize, and execute.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage triad for what early-career PMs should focus on first.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for new PMs
quotes.text: Avoid weasel words, answer first and then explain, own your problems.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A concrete communication checklist PMs can apply immediately in docs, meetings, and exec interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for new PMs
quotes.text: But if you can get in the habit early of answering a when question with a date, knowing how to use numbers to answer questions and honestly just learning from feedback and grade yourself after you get feedback on a doc or after a meeting or after answering a question in an elevator.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Tactical guidance for building executive-ready communication through specificity, metrics, and self-review loops.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for new PMs
quotes.text: Given the same amount of skill intelligence and resources, a product manager with a great innate ability to prioritize is going to generate 5X the impact of someone without that skill.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A striking quantitative claim that elevates prioritization as a primary driver of outsized PM impact.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for new PMs
quotes.text: I don't have the biggest brain in the world and I don't have the biggest working memory and I wasn't the most technical, but by trying to really get good at that prioritization, I think that's helped me and it still does.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that prioritization can compensate for perceived gaps in raw intellect or technical depth.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical ways to improve communication and prioritization
quotes.text: If you're asked a question and you explain and then maybe you get to the answer, if you just think, answer and then explain or sometimes answer and then shut up, that actually is a tactical thing you can do to get better at communicating.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A concrete communication tactic that reduces rambling and increases clarity in high-stakes conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical ways to improve communication and prioritization
quotes.text: There's no just simple trick unfortunately to prioritize other than ... I mean I think working backwards is a good technique to have impact to guide your prioritization.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Recommends a structured methodology (“working backwards”) as the way to improve prioritization rather than relying on quick hacks.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical ways to improve communication and prioritization
quotes.text: And then I think communication, the simple tip was just grade yourself after you communicate and try to just take a moment and after a while you'll just do it naturally to think about, "Gosh, how would I have answered that question better?"
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Introduces a self-review loop to continuously improve communication quality over time.

quotes.topic_title: Tactical ways to improve communication and prioritization
quotes.text: Awesome. And what's interesting about these three is if you look at the rest of the list, think big, understand technical trade offs, understand good design, I think what I would take away from this is those are the things you don't need to focus on that much when you're a new PM. Focus on, as you said, communication, prioritizing, executing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization for early PMs: de-emphasize “think big” and technical/design depth initially in favor of execution fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for senior PMs
quotes.text: take a minute at the beginning to say, could this be bigger? Could this be a bigger thing and more impactful than the initial idea, even if the initial idea sounds big?
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A simple repeatable prompt senior PMs can use to expand scope and ambition before committing to a direction.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for senior PMs
quotes.text: Earn trust is a huge one and that's kind of why I added it more recently. And it becomes even more important as you get into senior roles because I think it's truly the currency of a product leader or probably any leader in any function.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Frames trust as the core asset that unlocks influence and resources at senior levels.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for senior PMs
quotes.text: Trust is just built by repeatedly setting and meeting expectations. And I think that's a good mantra to think about as a FM. Am I meeting the expectations that I set? And not just doing good things, but calling your shots, forecasting, setting a goal, and then hitting it.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Turns “build trust” into a concrete operating system: make explicit commitments and reliably deliver on them.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for senior PMs
quotes.text: if you simply wake up every day trying to have the biggest impact you can, or if you're a leader trying to use your team to have the biggest impact you can in the company, which will influence how you build your roadmap and how you do every part of your day, that's a really good guiding light.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A prioritization north star that cuts through politics and careerism by anchoring decisions to impact.

quotes.topic_title: Top skills for senior PMs
quotes.text: It's just that the expectations, it goes from being a nice to have as a junior or first time PM to as you get a little more senior, hopefully if things work the way they should work, that's really how you're evaluated.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Clarifies how the performance bar shifts with seniority: impact becomes the primary evaluation criterion.

quotes.topic_title: Thinking like an owner and broadening scope
quotes.text: If you have a choice to work on something that's part of offense, something that drives the business.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A practical career heuristic: prioritize roles/projects tied to revenue/customer growth because they get disproportionate attention and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Thinking like an owner and broadening scope
quotes.text: executives wake up if something drives dollars or customers or offense things and it just maybe shouldn't be this way, but a little less interested in things that maybe less than a risk that just the risk never happens, it comes to pass or a cost center that operates a little more efficiently.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about incentives: “offense” work tends to be valued more than risk reduction or efficiency, shaping what gets rewarded.

quotes.topic_title: Thinking like an owner and broadening scope
quotes.text: one way to think about thinking big, especially as you grow in your career is most people operate within a box.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model (“the box”) for diagnosing when PM scope is artificially constrained by role expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Thinking like an owner and broadening scope
quotes.text: take that really wide view of what success for your product is and not have the blinders on its product or tech.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for broadening scope: define success cross-functionally rather than limiting ownership to roadmap/engineering execution.

quotes.topic_title: Thinking like an owner and broadening scope
quotes.text: you don't own marketing or you don't own this other function, but you own it until you find somebody else to own it.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A memorable ownership framework: temporarily “own” any blocker to outcomes until a clear functional owner is established.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With simple APIs, developers and PMs can get access to powerful AI models for transcription, summarization and dozens of other tasks that are fast, secure and production ready.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach—using simple APIs—to quickly add production-ready AI capabilities to products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: All of their models are researched and trained in house and continuously updated by their team of AI experts, which for a PM, makes it easy to build and ship new AI powered features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes the leverage PMs get from continuously updated, in-house models to ship AI features faster with less maintenance burden.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Product teams at startups and enterprises are using assembly AI to automatically transcribe and summarize phone calls and virtual meetings, detect topics and podcasts, pinpoint when sensitive content is spoken, redact PII from audio videos and way more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides concrete, high-signal examples of real-world AI use cases teams can apply immediately (summarization, topic detection, safety, PII redaction).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Visit assemblyai.com to try Assembly AI's API for free and start testing their models in their no code playground.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable next step for practitioners to validate AI capabilities quickly via a free API and no-code testing environment.

quotes.topic_title: Earning trust: lessons and Airbnb reflection
quotes.text: I think it's trying to really understand, work backwards from that person and what are their goals and what are their organization's goals and honestly spend the time and the energy to try to get to alignment in the same place.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A practical trust-building framework: start from the other person’s goals and invest time to reach real alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Earning trust: lessons and Airbnb reflection
quotes.text: And be willing, not just bullheaded, which I might have been earlier in my career, maybe still to many people, but charging forth what do I think's right but taking some more time to try to forge an alliance with someone because if you do that you're ultimately going to be more successful.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Counterbalances “being right” with relationship-building as a lever for execution and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Earning trust: lessons and Airbnb reflection
quotes.text: And I think that what I didn't do as much as I should have is obviously really partnering with the customer support leadership team as well.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A concrete retrospective example showing how under-investing in key stakeholder partnership can limit impact.

quotes.topic_title: Earning trust: lessons and Airbnb reflection
quotes.text: Well I would say that if you have a certain approach you may be believe it's the right one and it may be the right one, but if you don't build the support and the relationships that they're going to help carry that out and execute on that strategy, it may not get executed as well as you think it should be.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A memorable execution model: strategy quality isn’t enough—relationships are a prerequisite for successful delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Earning trust: lessons and Airbnb reflection
quotes.text: And trying to earn trust and to do it that way is a way to mitigate that risk that the right product and the right direction and the right strategy, it may not land if you don't have that support that you need.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Frames trust-building as explicit risk mitigation to ensure good strategies actually land in the org.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon retains people and builds operators
quotes.text: I think pretty quickly whether you're a fit for it or not.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Highlights Amazon as a high-signal environment where culture-fit becomes clear fast, which can guide hiring and self-selection.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon retains people and builds operators
quotes.text: this idea that hey, I could have this business and then figure out one metric or fitness function that determines success and then my job is to make that number go up and to the right.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A crisp operating model: define a single “fitness function” metric and orient execution around moving it.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon retains people and builds operators
quotes.text: You get the chance to read documents that make you learn more so than probably a slide deck.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Actionable process insight: written docs can drive deeper understanding and rigor than presentation-first communication.

quotes.topic_title: Why Amazon retains people and builds operators
quotes.text: You get a chance to be in weekly business reviews with really smart people and learn from that. Not just learn from your own experience but from everyone else in that room.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Points to WBRs as a scalable learning mechanism—leveraging shared operational reviews to compound organizational knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos and Jeff Wilke
quotes.text: Remember, this process doesn't have to be efficient because the prerequisite for efficiency is knowing where you're going.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that early-stage discovery can be intentionally inefficient until direction is clear.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos and Jeff Wilke
quotes.text: "You know what, maybe if you don't have a problem paragraph, there's not really a problem."
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A concrete working-backwards heuristic: if you can’t articulate the problem crisply, you may be solution-led.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos and Jeff Wilke
quotes.text: And so that was one thing, just that operational mindset and rigor that being a product leader is not just about building new things, it's about how well you run what you've already built.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: Reframes product leadership as ongoing operational excellence, not just shipping new features.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos and Jeff Wilke
quotes.text: And if you're really paying attention to the product that you operate, it will give you ideas for things you could do to double down on something that's happening well or to prevent something bad happening.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: An actionable operating model: use metrics and day-to-day signals to generate the roadmap (amplify wins, mitigate risks).

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos and Jeff Wilke
quotes.text: And the way he would run that meeting and enable you to get through a metrics meeting for the entire North American retail business in one hour.
quotes.speaker: Ian McAllister
quotes.context: A specific example of cadence-driven accountability: a tight, metrics-first weekly review that scales across a massive org.
